title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Spittal is a small fishing village, three quarters of a mile east of Tweedmouth.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Tweedmouth is a large irregularly built village at the south end of Berwick Bridge ; it is now an important railway station.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: It spans the Tweed from the castle-hill to the line on the Tweedmouth side, and from its great height and airy structure presents a most imposing appearance.

title: Tweed and Don; or, Recollections and reflections of an angler for the last fifty years ...
author: Locke, James.
snippet: To our piscatory  friends in the South, say at Richmond or Maidenhead, this is the great day of all the week for their sport of angling ! but here we have no such custom; and, I will venture to inform them, that from Tweedsmuir to Tweedmouth, not a line for salmon, salar, trout, or par, is cast on its waters, so well is the Sunday kept on Tweedside  ! ! But it may be said by some of our Southern brethren of the angle, What are you to do when in the country, on this day, if you do not fish, read ? No, not entirely so.

title: Letters of Thomas Gray.
author: Gray, Thomas
snippet: The first night we passed at Tweedmouth (77 miles); the next at Edinburgh  (53 miles); where lord Strathmore left the major and me, to go to Lennox-Love, (lord Blantyre's) where his aunt lives: so that afternoon and all next day I had leisure to visit the castle, Holyrood-house, Heriot's hospital, Arthur's seat, kc.

title: My first visit to Europe:
author: Dickinson, Andrew
snippet: Tweedmouth here expands into the German Ocean.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: From Tweedmouth to Scotts o'Harden One great troubled, clay-red sea, A wild, destructive, drift-strewn sea.

title: Murmurings from rugged waters.
author: Broomfield, James Polwarth. [from old catalog]
snippet: from its foundation, and was being hurled, maybe to Tweedmouth,  where the gleg eye o' some boat-builder would steer it where it would be fashioned for longer journey.

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance
author: Grant, James
snippet: The king'slances, and the riders of the east, west, and middlemarches, have scoured the whole land for me, fromTweedmouth to Solway sands.
